title: Notre-Dame: How to decipher the cathedral's old and new symbols
summary: An architectural masterpiece with religious, artistic, economic and political significance, the Parisian monument that will soon reopen is, above all, a fascinating repository of symbols, some dating back to the Middle Ages.

title: Notre-Dame reopening to be held indoors due to weather
summary: Saturday's reopening, which comes five years after the fire that devastated the famed Paris landmark, was moved inside after weather service Météo France forecast wind gusts of up to 80 kilometers per hour.

title: Thousands flee as Syrian insurgents advance to the country's third-largest city, government also loses control of Daraa
summary: The insurgents, led by the jihadi Hayat Tahrir al-Sham group, or HTS, have vowed to march to Homs and the capital, Damascus, Assad's seat of power. On Friday, the Syrian government lost control of the symbolic southern city of Daraa and most of the province, which was the cradle of the country's 2011 uprising, a war monitor said.

title: Macron meets with Socialists amid talks to form new government
summary: Socialist leader Olivier Faure said he was ready to negotiate, but that his party would not take part in a government led by a right-wing prime minister. He was criticized by other left-wing parties.

title: 'Dear Vladimir Vladimirovich ...' Russians are sending videos directly to Putin to talk about their local problems or the war in Ukraine
summary: Russians have taken to addressing the head of the Kremlin directly by sending him videos on social media. To talk about their local problems. But also to complain about the evils of the 'special operation' in Ukraine.

title: Pelicot rape trial: Co-defendants plead manipulation and lack of intent
summary: All week, lawyers for the men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot while her husband Dominique drugged her made their closing arguments. Their main defense is that their clients were not aware of committing rape.

title: Germany's Scholz sees 'joint' Ukraine strategy with Trump
summary: In recent weeks, Scholz has drawn criticism for speaking directly to Russian President Vladimir Putin but the chancellor vowed to continue supporting Ukraine 'to the best of our ability.'

title: Loss of Hama is another stinging defeat for the Syrian regime
summary: On Wednesday, the insurgent coalition led by Hayat Tahrir al-Sham took control of Hama, Syria's fourth-largest city, and is advancing rapidly towards Homs.

title: Pelicot rape trial: Co-defendants plead manipulation and lack of intent
summary: All week, lawyers for the men accused of raping Gisèle Pelicot while her husband Dominique drugged her made their closing arguments. Their main defense is that their clients were not aware of committing rape.

title: Romania's top court annuls presidential election
summary: The country's Constitutional Court made the decision following allegations of Russian interference, effectively canceling the second-round run-off that had been due to take place this weekend.

title: Musk's millions for Trump make him biggest US political donor
summary: Filings with the Federal Election Commission on Thursday showed Musk donated $238 million to America PAC, a political action committee he founded to support Trump and an additional $20 million going to RBG PAC, a group that used advertising to soften Trump's hardline reputation on the key voter issue of abortion.

title: European Union and Mercosur conclude free trade deal
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced negotiations with the South American bloc were complete.

title: Prince William to attend Notre-Dame cathedral reopening
summary: King Charles's son will represent the UK alongside dozens of heads of state and government at the ceremony.

title: Notre-Dame, 'France's most visited monument,' will welcome back millions of tourists
summary: The cathedral was the most visited monument in France before its closure, with 12 million visitors a year. It will reopen to the public on December 8.

title: South Korean political commentator Kim Ou-joon: 'President Yoon wanted to set up a National Assembly at his command'
summary: Popular commentator Kim Ou-joon was a target of the martial law imposed by South Korea's president, Yoon Suk Yeol. Having escaped the military who came to his home, he agreed to answer Le Monde's questions, shedding light on the president's plan.

title: Macron looks to reassure but refuses to take on 'responsibilities of others'
summary: In a televised address on Thursday, Macron pledged to appoint a prime minister 'within the next few days.' Despite increasing calls for his resignation, he firmly ruled out stepping down before the end of his term.

title: 'If the Socialists give the impression of wanting to form an alliance with Macron, it would open up political space for Mélenchon'
summary: It is difficult for the Socialists to compromise with the central bloc, at the risk of being accused of 'betrayal' by the radical left, explains political scientist Rémi Lefebvre.

title: In Turkey, a TV series that mirrors society: From ban to audience success
summary: 'Red Roses' tells the story of the encounter between a man and a woman from opposite backgrounds. He is an uncompromising Kemalist psychiatrist; she is a pious, troubled mother and member of a religious brotherhood, whose growing influence in the country is highlighted by the series.

title: Dogecoin, the crypto joke worth $66 billion
summary: Created in 2013 to parody bitcoin, dogecoin has thrived on Elon Musk's unconditional support. The election of Donald Trump has recently amplified the phenomenon, despite doubts about its economic utility.

title: South Korean president apologizes after martial law declaration
summary: Yoon stunned the nation and the international community Tuesday night by imposing martial law for the first time since the 1980s and deploying troops and helicopters to parliament. Lawmakers managed to vote down the decree, forcing Yoon to rescind the order in the early hours of Wednesday

title: Ethiopian wolves seen foraging for nectar are potential pollinators
summary: Insects aren't necessarily the only pollinators, but the Ethiopian wolf could be an unexpected candidate, as recent observations have shown that the canid is partial to the nectar of the large, cone-shaped flowers of the commonly named red-hot poker plant.

title: Jean Pisani-Ferry: 'Why are we experiencing such a contradiction between the universality of problems and the fragmentation of responses?'
summary: In an interview with 'Le Monde,' the economist proposes new rules of the game for cooperative management of the global commons.

title: In Greece, thousands of cameras will monitor traffic violations
summary: The government has unveiled a plan to install 1,388 cameras across Greece by 2026 to fight road accidents, which are often caused by traffic violations.

title: Notre-Dame: How the Catholic edifice became a place to celebrate national unity
summary: Since the Middle Ages, the cathedral, built by the Church, has been the scene of sumptuous ceremonies associating political power with religion. This tradition was taken up by Napoleon I, then by the republicans, who eventually made it 'the nation's parish.'

title: Zelensky slams Putin after Russian strikes kill 12
summary: At least 10 people were killed in the southern city of Zaporizhzhia, while two were killed in Zelensky's hometown of Kryvyi Rig, officials said.

title: To solve budget impasse, Macron banks on emergency 'special law' and new bill in 2025
summary: With efforts to pass the 2025 budget having failed, President Emmanuel Macron said a special law would be introduced in the next 10 days to ensure the government could keep operating after December 31.

title: 'The next trade wars launched by Donald Trump are going to be much more serious'
summary: Raghuram Rajan, former chief economist of the International Monetary Fund and former governor of India's central bank, is calling for 'a change in the IMF's governance structure' to 'give more power to emerging countries.'

title: Romania: Pro-Georgescu videos linked to mysterious Polish 'influencer agency'
summary: Romanian influencers were approached by a company that concealed its true identity in order to broadcast videos in support of the far-right pro-Russian candidate.

title: On the slopes of the world's largest indoor ski resort in Shanghai, fun is more important than the climate
summary: The L + Snow Indoor – with its 60-meter mountain, artificial snow and lifts – attracts curious visitors and enthusiasts, indifferent to the high energy costs of the huge refrigeration warehouse.

title: South Korea ruling party MPs walk out ahead of impeachment vote
summary: The ruling People Power Party's walkout means the bill is short of the members needed to pass it. Before the vote, South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol had apologized for imposing martial law last week.

title: EU, Mercosur seal free trade deal in a setback for France
summary: After 25 years of negotiations, the European Commission and five South American nations have agreed on a text to facilitate trade. The agreement still has to be validated by the member states and the European Parliament. France is opposed to the treaty.

title: Romania's presidential election canceled over TikTok disinformation investigation
summary: Pro-Russian candidate Calin Georgescu said the decision amounted to an 'organized coup d'état'. Democracy was brought 'to its knees,' pro-European Elena Lasconi said.

title: In France's Brittany, the weariness of left-wing voters
summary: Several thousand people marched in the city of Rennes on Thursday to defend the civil service. In this social-democratic stronghold, the resignation of Michel Barnier's government is fuelling concern and mistrust of politicians.

title: Prince William to meet with Trump while in Paris for Notre-Dame reopening
summary: The last time Prince William met Donald Trump was in 2019, when the then-US president was on a state visit to the UK.

title: Reopening of Notre-Dame: A behind-the-scenes look at the ceremony
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (5/5). Republican, ecclesiastical and televisual − these are the three elements of the ceremonies that will return Paris's cathedral to worship, on December 7 and 8, in the presence of a host of heads of state and prelates.

title: Ukraine's Zelensky arrives in Paris for Notre-Dame reopening
summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky touched down in Paris on Saturday to attend the cathedral's reopening and to meet with his French counterpart.

title: Notre-Dame could have collapsed in April 2019. Here's how firefighters saved the cathedral from total destruction
summary: On April 15, 2019, the roof and spire of the famous Paris monument went up in smoke. It was a disaster, but one that could have been far worse. Using exclusive 3D modeling to reconstruct the fire, Le Monde identified the crucial decision that saved the monument.

title: Notre-Dame's 340,000 donors
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (3/5). Two days after the April 15, 2019 fire, pledges to rebuild the Paris cathedral had already amounted to €900 million. After five years of restoration work, the reopening, on December 7 and 8, will honor the largest donors, alongside heads of state.

title: What it took to rebuild Notre-Dame within five years
summary: 'The story of Notre-Dame' (1/5). Partially destroyed by a fire on April 15, 2019, Emmanuel Macron promised the cathedral would be rebuilt within five years. Due to reopen on December 7, Le Monde looks back on the five years that made this challenge possible.

title: Notre-Dame reopening: Trump, Macron and the 'strong men'
summary: The French President, who is due to meet the US president-elect on the sidelines of Notre-Dame's reopening on Saturday, is cultivating personal diplomatic contacts, relying on his powers of persuasion. This method delivers contrasting results.

title: Paris's Notre-Dame cathedral celebrates grand reopening five years after fire: Follow our live blog
summary: The Notre-Dame cathedral is reopening on Saturday with a weekend of invite-only ceremonies, five years after the 2019 fire that ravaged the world heritage landmark. Follow our live coverage here.

title: Syrian rebels say they are encircling Damascus
summary: Anti-Assad rebel forces advanced further south on Saturday, taking most of the key Daraa region, according to reports by a UK-based war monitor.

title: Ghana's VP Bawumia and former president Mahama face off in election
summary: Polls suggest former president John Dramani Mahama is the favorite to win the presidential election on Saturday, December 7.

title: In France, neo-cafés are booming
summary: The traditional black coffee served at bar counters is becoming increasingly less popular in France. A new wave of coffee shops is emerging to cater to the cravings of a younger, more connected and discerning clientele who seek a gourmet coffee experience.

title: Putin can't help Assad's regime as Syrian rebels continue lighting advance
summary: Focused on its war in Ukraine, the Russian air force is no longer in a position to turn the situation around, as it did in 2015. Moscow could lose its two strategic bases in Syria.

title: Trump, Zelensky meet in Paris as Macron hosts three-way talks
summary: The meeting is taking place at the Elysée Palace, ahead of Notre-Dame Cathedral's grand reopening, after five years of reconstruction.
